title: Carlton Bank Walk Route

images.title: Cleveland Way, Carlton Moor by David Brown, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cleveland Way, Carlton Moor

images.title: Mick Garratt / View From the Summit of Carlton Moor
images.caption: View From the Summit of Carlton Moor. Taken on an overcast evening to show the effect of yellow fields on the view. Carlton village is left of centre

images.title: Carlton Moor Trig pillar by David Brown, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Carlton Moor Trig pillar. From here there are extensive views of Teesside including Middlesbrough and Redcar to the north as well as the surrounding moorland. Roseberry Topping can also be clearly seen from the summit in a north-easterly direction.

images.title: View from Carlton Moor by Christopher Hilton, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: View from Carlton Moor

images.title: Lord Stones Cafe by Richard Webb, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Lord Stones Cafe

images.title: Mick Garratt / Final Climb up Carlton Bank
images.caption: Final Climb up Carlton Bank

description: This walk climbs to Carlton Bank on Carlton Moor in the North York Moors National Park. You can start the walk from the car park at Lord Stones Country Park which lies just to the east of the hill. From here you can pick up the Cleveland Way National Trail and follow the waymarked footpath south west for just over half a mile to the 408 metre high summit of Carlton Bank. There's a trig pillar here marking the summit point of Carlton Moor. There are wonderful views here over the village of Carlton in Cleveland to the hills and countryside beyond. The route then descends to the gliding club building before passing the old quarries and returning to the car park.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: For a longer circular walk which explores Lord Stones and Whorl Hill Wood see the Carlton in Cleveland Walk. This starts and finishes from the village to the north. Head east and you could visit the noteworthy Wainstones. These fascinating sandstone rocky outcrops include a number of interesting Bronze Age carvings.

display_address: Lordstones Country Park, Raisdale Road, Low Broomflatt, Bilsdale Midcable, Carlton in Cleveland, North Yorkshire, York and North Yorkshire, England, TS9 7JQ, United Kingdom
